captions.content: The Mitochondria is an extremely important part of eukaryotic cells.
In order for cells to function, they have to be able to go through a multitude of chemical reactions.
Every chemical reaction requires energy!
In order to use this energy, the energy must be in the form of an ATP molecule.
If you look closer at the mitochondria, you can see that it is a membrane bound organelle.
An even closer inspection shows that it is actually a double membrane organelle.

This means that there is an outer phospholipid bilayer membrane creating the border of the organelle and an inner phospholipid bilayer membrane creating increased surface area within the organelle itself.
This outer membrane is smooth and makes up the border of the organelle.
It is composed of similarly to the cell membrane in its composition of phospholipids and proteins.
It also consists of special proteins called Porins.
These Porins are integral membrane proteins that specifically allow the movement of necessary molecules to pass through it.
This outer membrane is freely permeable to nutrient molecules, ions, and energy molecules like ATP and ADP molecules.
Inner membrane of mitochondria is more complex in structure.
It has a very large surface area that is bent into number of folds known as Cristae.
This folding help to increase the surface area inside the mitochondria which is extremely important for efficiency.
The cristae and proteins of the inner membrane aid in the production of ATP molecules.
The inner membrane is the location of various chemical reactions that enable metabolism.
This inner membrane is strictly permeable and it is permeable only to Oxygen, CO2, ATP as it helps in regulating transfer of these metabolites across the membrane.
If you look at the mitochondria in cross section, you can see that there are two distinctive regions created by the double membrane.
First, there is the area between the outer membrane and the inner membrane.
This is called the inter membrane space.
As mentioned earlier, the Inner membrane has many folds known as cristae.
These cristae increase the available surface area to enhance the productivity of cellular respiration.
This is very important for efficiency of the organelle.
The more surface area of inner membrane there is, the more enzymatic reactions can occur along it to convert energy into ATP molecules.
The fluid inside the inner membrane of the mitochondria is called the matrix.
The mitochondrial matrix content is completely enclosed by the inner membrane.
Most of the chemical reactions of aerobic cellular respiration processes happen in the inner membrane of the mitochondria due to high concentration of enzymes and proteins.
These enzymes are important for the synthesis of ATP molecules, mitochondria ribosome, t RNA and mitochondria DNA.
This is one reason why the inner membrane of the mitochondria is so specific to its permeability.
The function of the mitochondria is to take the energy from a glucose molecule and transform that energy into the useable form within ATP molecules.
This process, known as cellular respiration, is vital for eukaryotic cells and would not be possible without the mitochondria.
